S7 u. 13 - Prawa budowlanego dołączam: 1. oryginał dzienna budowy, 1 otułodzenie Kierownika budowy: + ożgodności wykonania obiektu budowlanego z projektem budzkznsm I warunki pozwołenk na budzę orz przepi, + o doprowodzenin do nalzytego ster I porządi terenu budowy, a takze = ve razie borzystania żule, riedij nieruchomości, budyn leb loko 1. otwiadezenie o waściwym zagowpodarownniu terenów przyeghch, jezeli chpłoctacja wybudzwanego obiektu Jest uzależniona od ich odpowiiego zagospodarowania 4. inwentaryzację geodczyjną powykonawczą. 3. protołoń: bada sprze: + imialacji: wodno-kanaliacyjn, eetryczrej gazowej przewodów kominowych. 46. pobeirdzerie, zgodności odrębnym przepi, odbłoi wyłonanych przyłączy 7. pozwolenie na budowę wrz z doborentacją techniczną obiek ( załączyć do wgląd, 5. oedodzenie o braku arzechwu PIS PIP, PSP, 3... kopię twiadectwa charaliesyk nergetcznej budynki. UWAGA: Do składania wniosków o wydanie pozwolenia na użytkowanie obiektu (budynków) jak i odbioru decyzji o pozwoleniu na użytkowanie, uprawnieni sq właicietele lub osoby posiadające upoważnienia pisemne od wlaicieiela_; potwierdzoną. przez_organ odniniatracji włazmoręcznoicią podpliw właicieicl,

Text ING: Second-Hand Smoke: TheMyth and TheReality Many non-smokers are annoyed by cigarette smoke. This is a reality thats been with us fora time: Lately; however; many non-smokers have come to believe that cigarette smoke in the air can actually cause disease. But; infact; there is little evidence and certainly nothing which broves  scientifically-that  cigarette  smoke causes   disease tn  non - smokers: Weknow this statement may seem biased But it is supported by findings and views of independent scientists-includingsome ofthe tobacco industrys biggest critics. Lawrence Garfinkel of the American Cancer Society for exam- ple. Mr: Garfinkel, who is the Societys chiefstatistician, publisheda study in 1981 covering over 175,000 people, and reported that 'passive smoking" had " very little, ifany" effect on lung cancer rates amongnon-smokers may have seen reports stating that in the course of an evening; a non-smoker could breathe in an amount of smoke equivalent to several cigarettesor more. But a scientific study by the Harvard School of Fublic Health; conducted in various public places, found that non-smokers might inhale anywhere from L/lOOth to L/1OOth of one filter cigarette per hour At that rate, it would take you at least 4 days to inhale the equivalent ofa single cigarette  Often our own concerns about our health can take an unproven claim and magnify it out of all proportion; SO, what begins as a misconception turns intoa frightening myth. "second-hand smoke" one of these myths? We hope the 1 information weve offeredwillhelpyou sort out someofthe realities: { RJReynolds Tobacco Company long! You

Text ING: GA CDC-Smoking-Teens, 740 Smoking Teens Respond to Cigarette Advertising ATLANTA (AP) The three most heavily advertised cigarette brands depicted by Joe CameL the Marlboro Man and the couples of Newport captured 86 percent of the teen-age market accounting for only 35 percent of overall sales, according t0 new study released Thursday The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said that based on the data showing that advertising influences brand preference among teens, legislation may be needed t0 restrict cigarette advertising_ The results are pretty striking; We were shocked by the magnitude in the difference said Michael Eriksen director of the CDCs Oflice on Smoking and Health. Text Adam: GA CDC-Smoking-Teens, 740 Smoking Teens Respond to Cigarette Advertising ATLANTA (AP) "Tbe three most heavily advertised cigaretie brands_ depicted by Joe Camel, the Marlboro Man and the fun couples of Newport. captured 86 percent of the tecn-age market while accounding for only 35 percent of overall sales, aecording to a new study released Thursday. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said that based - on the data showing that advertising influences brand preference among teens, legislation may be needed to restriet cigarette adyertising. **The results are preity striking. We were shocked by the magnitude in the difference," said Michael Eriksen, director of the CDC's Office on Smoking and Health. "I shows that advertising not only works, but it works better for teens than adulis.* s it true? Absolutely," said John P. Pierce, head of the Cancer Prevention and Conteol Program at the University of. California, San Diego, Cancer Cenier in La Jolla. * What we're seeing here is, the kids are smoking only the brands ... with huge adverńising campaign, not the generie brands." „About 3 million teens are smokers and they sconsumme nearly 1 billion packs a year. Seventy percent of teen smokers become regular snokers by age 18. Eriksen said teenę are more vulnerable to advertising by the tobacco industry, with its images of independent, sacial, and - sophisticated people who also smoke. "Tobacco companies spend $4.6 billion a year in advertising and promotions, but insist they don't target children. They do support campaigns to discourage children from smoking, most notably spending hundreds of fhousands of dollars to print płacards warning teen-agers that buying cigaretes is illegal. Just as you don't bleme General Motors for children who steal cary, nor should you say cigarette brands initiate kids smoking,” said "Thomas Lauria, a spokesman for the Tobacco Institute, an industry group. He polnted to the June decision by the Federal Trade Commission to end an investigation of the Jae Camel campaign without filing a compłaint. The FTC said at the time that it Jacked evidence to support aliegations that the campaign encourages children to smoke. - FTC spokeswoman Bonnie Jansen said that the information used in the decision is not made public and could not say whether the commission was aware of the CDC report. - "The report was based on a 1993 survey of 702 smokers ages 12-18 - włose brand preference was known. Mallboro was the most popular Cigarette, aecounting for 60 percent of teen sales, while Camel and Newport each grzbbed about 13 percent of the teen market. Marlboro E was also the most popular cigarette overall, with a 23.5 percent w market share, according to the CDC. KJ "That same year, Marlboro, Camel and Newport ranked first, second za and thisd in advertising expenditures, Maclboro, made by Philip "| Moris, alone spent $75 million on advertising. ej Adverising most clearly worked for Cartel cigarettes. Text Adam: * WILLIAM A. KLODMAN SECOND VICE PRESIDENT ATMI  William Klopman is chairman and chief executive ośśicer of Burlington  Industries. He was elected second vice president of the American  Textile Hanufacturers Institute at the Institute's 1580 annual neet-  ing.  Klopman joined Burlington in 1946 as a sales traineć and has served  in various sales and executive capacitias, He was president of  the Klopman division rom 1963 until 1971. ,  Xlopman was. appointed group vice president of Burlingron Zndustries  in 1971 and executive vice president in 1972. He was elacted to  che Board of Dizectors'in 1973, and was named president of Surling-  ton April 23, 1974, He was elacted chairman, president and chief  executive officer $eptenber 15, 1976, and hela thosę three titles  until February 2, 1978, when a president was elected by the comgany's  Board of Directors.  He is a membar oś the Board Of Dizectors of Western Electric Corp.,  the North Carolina National Bank Corp., the North Carolina National  Bank, and the Chamber of Commerca of the United states. He has  been chaixman of the ATMI International Trade Committee and sexves on  the Instituta's Executive Comnittee. He is on the Policy Committeę  of the Business Round Table, and is a menber of The Business Councii.  Be is a trustea of The Wesley Long Hospital in Greensboro, N.C.  Klopman is a native of New Jersey, and is a graduate of Williams  College. : > h  "©  R u p $ R

Text ING: Busheels Committee Karen Kerrigan President Small Business Survival Committee Karen Kerrigan president of the 40,000 member Small Business Survival Committee (SBSC); nationwide nonprofit, nonpartisan small business advocacy organization representing America's small business and entrepreneurial sector.  SBSC works to promote policics and reforms which foster economic growth and entrepreneurship. Ms: Kerrigan is nationally recognized spokesperson on wide range of public policy issues, who has testified numerous times on behalf of small business interests before the US Congress She has appeared on such television programs as CNBC $ America'$ Nenwork; C-SPAN, The Wall Street Journal Report, European Business News The Home Business Show, NET s Capitol Watch and writes twice-monthly syndicated column for the American City Business Jourals an influential network of more than local business joumals nationwide: Ms. Kerrigan also president of the Small Business Survival Foundation, research and education orgarization that studies the impact of government policy on entrepreneurship and economic growth. She is also principal in Capitol Hill Rescarch, political and economic research service SBSC, which was recognized by Your Company magazine as One of the most powerful small business lobbying groups in Washington; D.C has been cited by Investor $ Business Daily; The Wall Street Journal, The Washington Times; The Washington The New York Times; National Journal, Business Week; Entrepreneur, Fortune Magazine, Bloomberg Business News, The Boston Herald The Philadelphia Inquirer; The Rush Limbaugh Show, The Michael Regan Show and hundreds of local newspapers 1 1320 [8th Strcet Nw Suite Z00 Washington; DC 20036 Tel: (202) 785-0238 Fax (202) 822-8118 WWW, sbsc org SLRYIVALL Talking - sixty senves Post;

Determined the status of the risk assessment and plans for press conference releasing the risk assessment from EPA staff working on the risk assessment and from EPA press staff: Researched the non-cancer risk assessment issues related the children'$ respiratory effects section of the risk assessment and proposed strategy for pre-empting the release of the risk assessment on that issue Dralted press statement to this effect. Text Adam: . - CEZ HE PHILIP MORRIS U. S$. A. h - ONET JNTER-OFFICE CORRESPOKDENCE FE 8 RICHNOHD, FIRGINIA * Toi « Dr. W. R. Johnson mite: January 30, 1978 „Pom 1 E.'B. Sanders C78-2m348 - Subject: «, G]ycoside Ester Patent amd Project . Some time ago I suggested to Eric Rundberg the pos- sibility of using sugar glycosides as pyrolytie precursors 8 A .. for the generation of alcoholic fllavorants. In addition,  - a further applicatiom of such a concept was discussed; - * namely, the use of ],]-dimethylallyl B-D-gluconyranoside as an isoprene release agent wia pyrolytie formation of 1,l- dimethyłally! alcohol followed by therma] dehydration. The -. synthesis of 1,l-dimethylallyl 2,3,4,6-tetra-0-acetyl-g-0- - glucopyranoside was carried out $uccessfully, Before this *.s compound was converted to.the deacetyjated glycoside, however, SJ -..y, jtowas pyrołyzed in order to ascertain whether any isoprene app ie was indeed released. In actuality no isóprene was detected. 2 *;'0m-theother hand a large amount of acetic acid was noted. | - nii - Since Flavor Development has expressed interest in acetic A acid-release compounds for some time, the idea occurred to ; Eric that' such a compound might be useful despite the fact that isoprene was not. formed. „A sample of the acetylatad głycoside was delivered to Frank Crayton who injected it into a Marlboro and placed the - treated cigareńtes on the SEF panel. The cigarette with the acety]ated glycoside proved to be less "spicy" at. the 0.00: © probability level and was preferred overall at the 0.12 probać bility level. (See Booth Test Data Summary Sheet, tHarch 18, 1976.) It was originally assumed that the subjective improve- ment noted in the panel test was due to either acetic acid or 2-methyl-2-butene - the pyrolysis product from the aglycane - or a combination of the two congounds. As a consequence, we sent some D-glucosepentaacetate to Flavor Development for evaluatiom. The effect. of the fully acetylated Sugar was h completely negative. =) =) The next development was a result of the observation of © Bill Johnson that the amounts of acetic acid or Ż-nethyl-2- 3 butene which could be delivered to: mainstream smoke were too Gi small to rationalize the subjeetive effect; andi the discovery of a patent which disclosed the use of peresterified sugars i as acid-release compounds. in tobacco. (See Ashburn, U.Ś. OE . 2,766,146.) I suggested to Eric that the project be temporć » = iż jeży arily abandoned until we could design experiments which would | 4 2, give us some indication of exaętly what was going on. Eric, NOSI either despite of or because of my comments, proceeded with the Ż% =: ŚŚ ci AE ac a i ET AEG AA EE a KO

Text Adam: Pa: KU /ó pil AH Glina MEMORANDUM May 17, 1989 To: J. R. Reid FROM: 1. H. Gaina SUBJECT: B451 Status Report = X have previously reportęd on investigations involving inorganic sulfnr salts as filter additives for the reduction of NOx deliver- . iea in mainstream tobacco smoke (1,2). This memo will update activity not previously sumtarized and will outline currently | planned future investigations as well as identify pereeived problems in achieving the desired goals. Previous work employed hand-made cavity filters and demonstrated the apparent efficacy of sodium sulfite and sodium metabisuifite in reducing mainstream deliveries of NOx and low molecular weight carbonyls. More recent work has included evaluation of other filter constructions, comparison of "different charcoal samples, examination of alternative cavity loading procedures, and has ą focused on development of methods to incorporąte sodium sulfite into a more conventional machine made filter. The approaches investigated in this Jast category are the result of extensive - consultations with Celanese parsonnel and Lorillard experts. in filter preparation: RESULTS 1. Wo significant differences in HCN removal from mainstream smoke are observed when comparing equal amounts of Goal based charcoal to coconut based Charcoal with similar mesh sizes in cavity filters (3). 2. Reducing the charcoal's meshigize by pulverizing with a mortar and pestle does nęć efłect the HCN removal observed with charcoal from eitheż-sońrce. 3. The maximum solubility o! sodium sulfite in watar at ambient temperature is zpproximately 30 grams. in 100 mL, which corresponds to a saturatedi aqueous solution of about 23% by weight sodium sulfite. Ki 4. Sałturated aqueous sodium sulfite lacks sufficient surface. |) tension to coat the walls of a 1.5mm ID hollow fiber. 3 8 * U n

Text Adam: . = SE PHILIP MORRIS U.S.A. © INTER - OFFICE CORRESPONDENCE : 100 Park Avenue, New Yark, N.Y. 10047 Tr © JL J. Morgan Dute: ilovember 26, 1980 From: don K. Zoler Subjech + Merit Ultra Lights Here is a summary of the latest information avai TM e on Merit Ultra Lights. It is based on the Brand's performance in Des Moines and Sacrifnte-siące. , - the Peoria and Indianapolis test markets are too early to read. 1. Harket Shares - Merit Ultra Lights was sold to distributors in the Des fiofnes and Sacramento markets the week of Septenber 26. The Harket Research Departent has been tracking its market share per- formance in two ways; 1) estimated weekly shares based on factory sales and estimated industry volume, and Ż) I.C.C. data which is based on the sales of one Targe distributor in each market to iis retail accounts, In most introductions, market share data are the hardest and most reliable information available. Unfortunately, this is not the case with fłerit Ultra lights for two reasons. The primary one is that price increase buying has distorted sales and share readings. This has been especial|y true in Sacramento as several major distributors ordered very heavily in Septenber and October in anticipation of the price increase. Moreover, in the latest two weeks, market shares in both markets have been enormously affected with the price increase actually taking place, Secondly, im Sacramento, a number of large retai] food chains - responsible for a sizeable percentage of that market 's carton cigarette volume, have not accepted distribution of Merit Ultra Lights because it's'a tóst market brand. This problem would not have occurred if the Brand were nationally distributed. Below is a recap of the I.C.C. market shares for four weeks ending Novenber 14. 1.C.€. Text ING: PHILIP MORRIS INCORPORATED INTER-OFFICE CORRESPONDENCE 1875 Eye Street. Suite 500 , Washington D.C. 20006 To: Distribution Date; May 19 , 1983 From: Michael eMita Subject: Hatch Bill (S. 772) The attached memo from Bill Fritts describes informal luncheon coJversation which he had yesterday with Dr David Sundwall WJo the staff member of Senator Hatch Labor Committee pecializing in health matters and the closest this legislition. Sundwall'$ comments cannot be as firm statement of Senator Ha tch position , but might provide some valuable insight as what might be an acceptable result Erom the discussions with HHS Not brought out in Bill's memo is Sundwall response to the Shallenge tnat the unqualified statement containing the word "causes is inappropr iate since not everyone who smokes actually contracts these ilinesses Sundwall response was that perhaps Senator Hatch would agree Ehe substitution of the phrase increases the risk of" It should be pointed out that Sundwall information on pr evious occasions has pr ovea to be not entirely accurate but I think it is important make all information available those who will actually be involved the discussions with HBS Amk = iec Attachment Distribution: Mr Hugh Cullman James Bowling Mr Alexander Holtzman TI: Mr Horace Kornegay- Mr sam Chilcote CEB: Mr stan Temko TIMN 176589 m read
Text Adam: a PHILIP MORRIS INCORPORATED INTER-OFFICE CORRESPONDENCE 1875 Eye Stram NI. Sulto 800, Washington, D.C. 20006  To:  . Distribution Date: May 19, 1983  From: „ Michael A. beMita  Subject; . Hatch Bi11 (8. 772) The attached memo from Bi11 Fritts describes an informal luncheon conversation which he had yesterday with Dr. David Sundwall, wano is the staff member Of Senator Hatch's Labor Committee specializing in health matters and the closest to this legislation. Dr. Sundwall's comments cannot be read as a firm statament of Senator Hatch's position, but might prówide som2 valuable insight as to what might be an acceptable result from the discussions with HHS, Not brought out in BiLl's memo is Sundwall's response to the challenge thąt the unqualifięd statement containing the word "causes" is inappropriate, since not everyone who smokes actually contracts these illneszes. Sundwall's response was that perhaps Senator Hatch would agree to the substitution of the phrase "increases the risk of". It should be pointed out that Sundwall's information on previous occasions has proved to be not entirely accurate,  . put I think it is important to make all information available to those who will actuałly be involved in the discussions with HHS.  ARD iec Attachment Distribution: Mr. Hugh Cullman Mr. James C. Bowling Mr. Alexander Holtzman TI: Mr. Horace Kornegay"/ Mr. Sam Chilcote CB: Mr. Stan Temko " TIMN 176589
Text Adam pl: a PHILIP MORRIS INCORPORATED INTER-OFFICE CORRESPONDENCE 1875 Eye Stram NI. Sulto 800, Washington, D.C. 20006  To:  . Distribution Date: May 19, 1983  From: „ Michael A. beMita  Subject; . Hatch Bi11 (8. 772) The attached memo from Bi11 Fritts describes an informal luncheon conversation which he had yesterday with Dr. David Sundwall, wano is the staff member Of Senator Hatch's Labor Committee specializing in health matters and the closest to this legislation. Dr. Sundwall's comments cannot be read as a firm statament of Senator Hatch's position, but might prowide som2 valuable insight as to what might be an acceptable result from the discussions with HHS, Not brought out in BiLl's memo is Sundwall's response to the challenge that the unqualified statement containing the word "causes" is inappropriate, since not everyone who smokes actually contracts these illneszes. Sundwall's response was that perhaps Senator Hatch would agree to the substitution of the phrase "increases the risk of". It should be pointed out that Sundwall's information on previous occasions has proved to be not entirely accurate,  . put I think it is important to make all information available to those who will actually be involved in the discussions with HHS.  ARD iec Attachment Distribution: Mr. Hugh Cullman Mr. James C. Bowling Mr. Alexander Holtzman TI: Mr. Horace Kornegay"/ Mr. Sam Chilcote CB: Mr. Stan Temko " TIMN 176589

Text ING: PHIIP MORRIS U. S A. INTER-OFFICE, CORRESPONDENCE Richmond, Virginia To: Dr. K S. Houghton Date: November 4, 1991 From: Baldwin Subject: Paper Technology Update for the Week of October 28 Reduced Sidestream Trim Cigarettes were made in Louisville with two different papers that had been prepared at Kimberly-Clark by single-step papermaking operation that incorporated processing aids, Production   control cigarettes also were collected   for comparison. All the cigarettes have been   submitted for analysis, and they will screened for sidesteam visibility and subjective   acceptability. No problems were encountered during manufacturc Analytical smoking data and sidestream visibility results will be available this week: One additional shipment of  four   pallets 10-062-A paper was approved for production use Full Circumference Reduced Sidestream Cigarette All   the recent Cigarette model requests were completed in thc Scmiworks. These requests   included Ecusta esite  base  papers  with varous  Sizings and University Maine magnesite paper: Different models included the 55 paper with monopotassium phosphatel potassium succinate mixturc and the Original 45 paper with succinate  CMC; and MAP: Papers   from the latest   mill were received early   this week, and  porosity measurements on the different papers are in progress: A meeting was held on October 29 to determine  which  samples of  commercially available ground calcium carbonate warrant further development: Samples were identified and_ handshee requests were submitted in preparation for papermaking at the University of Maine later this quarter: Cigarette Specifications 1 A meeting  will held this weck t0 discuss the results   of the   response   surface study with Purchasing; QA and Manufacturing Services management: Quarterly meetings with these groups are planned t0 inform them of the results of any relevant Studies_ Sherry magne @Jm' glmn' Paper :

Text Adam: ii Momis USA CONFDENTLA, | PHILIP MORRIS U,$.A, INTEROFFICE CORRESPONDENCE Richmond, Virginia To: K. Edwards 4 „Date: August 15, 1995 Ejeż Sz From: Śeźińmiómańm and skies Subject: Special Analysis - Analytical Investigation - Filter Material (Activity 7A23) Plug and CA marerials from both before and after tile installation were received in separaje mason jars to determine analytical differences or simiłarinies in the chemicał profiles for these samples. , In addition, a le sample coated with some of ue epozy/cement material was alo submitted in a stmiłar fashion. These samples were ideniified from the information supplied as: Purple Dot Plugs 0660/0690 - FT-777 Tow from Bay 7, 8/2/95 A 08:45 before tilę (control) Purple Dot Plugs FE-777 Tow from Bay 7 afier tile installation, 8/4/95 A 10:30 (test) Epoxy - € - Cement, 8-400 Summitville Leb, 8/3/95 A (tle + epoxy/cement) CA material FT-777 from Bay 7 (before and after tile installation) MSDS sheets for both the Part A Resin and Part B Catalyst were also obtained. No identification as to the supplier or nature of the CA was provided. A weighed portion of each sample was thermily desorbed using a Chrompack TCT/PTI and anelyzed by GC/MS using an HP 5890 GC and an HP 3989 mass specirometer. Examination of the total ion chromatograms (TIC) obtained for the cured epoxy sample showed the presence of at least three sets of major components ("markers") that were chemically similar and a numbee of minor components. Reference materials for each of these compounds would hase to be. obtained to furtter identify these matesials providing commercial availability. ILis important bo note that sufficient thermal energy was used to evolve these compounds ftom the cured epoxy material. This application of thermal treatment was necessary to maximize the concentration OĆ these components, Overlays of the TIC's for the plug from both before and after tile installation showed no significant differences between ench of ile two traces. The TIC's for the CA material also appeazed to be quitę similar. The. presence of the, rnarker components or profiles wete not observed in cither tte plugs or CA marezials. GE: FH. Alonso (M/C) R. These samples were ideniified from the information supplied as: Purple Dot Plugs 0660/0690 - FT-777 Tow from Bay 7, 8/2/95 A 08:45 before tile (control) Purple Dot Plugs FE-777 Tow from Bay 7 afier tile installation, 8/4/95 A 10:30 (test) Epoxy - € - Cement, 8-400 Summitville Leb, 8/3/95 A (tle + epoxy/cement) CA material FT-777 from Bay 7 (before and after tile installation) MSDS sheets for both the Part A Resin and Part B Catalyst were also obtained. No identification as to the supplier or nature of the CA was provided. A weighed portion of each sample was thermily desorbed using a Chrompack TCT/PTI and anelyzed by GC/MS using an HP 5890 GC and an HP 3989 mass specirometer. Examination of the total ion chromatograms (TIC) obtained for the cured epoxy sample showed the presence of at least three sets of major components ("markers") that were chemically similar and a numbee of minor components. Reference materials for each of these compounds would hase to be. obtained to furtter identify these matesials providing commercial availability. ILis important bo note that sufficient thermal energy was used to evolve these compounds ftom the cured epoxy material. This application of thermal treatment was necessary to maximize the concentration OC these components, Overlays of the TIC's for the plug from both before and after tile installation showed no significant differences between ench of ile two traces. The TIC's for the CA material also appeazed to be quite similar. The. presence of the, rnarker components or profiles wete not observed in cither tte plugs or CA marezials. GE: FH. Alonso (M/C) R. Text ING: PHILIP MORRIS COMPANIES INC, 120 PAAK AVENUE NEYTOAKNI100i7 TELEPHONE (2121 880-5030 26,1995 TO: The Board of Directors of Philip Morris Companies Inc FROM: Geoffrey C Bible Earlier this week; we discovered that an ingredient supplied by Celanese which is used in the manufacture of filter material was contaminated with bactcria_ The manufactured product containing this material gave off an unpleasant odor, which is how we detected the problem initially. We immediately ceased production, cleaned out the tanks and pipes containing the material, and did not resume production until substitute material was Obtained from another vendor: We also put hold on all of the affected product that was within our control: Ongoing testing revealed that the presence of the bacteria triggered chain reaction which led to the formation of byproduct by the name of methyl isothiocyanate (MITC), toxic substance: MITC can cause various forms of discomfort, including eye, nose and throat irritation, dizziness coughing_ and wheezing; if inhaled in sufficient quantities We have no evidence that any of the affected product reached the retail distribution channel.  However, it is possible that somc of it did; and WC cannot easily or quickly verify that fact: Accordingly, because we are with toxic substance; we decided out of an abundance of caution to institute nationwide consumer recall_ result; we are recalling in the U.S: domestic market every pack of cigarettes, both at retail and wholesale; of all of the brands shown on the attached list: That recall was launched at 3;00 p.m , which is within one day of our becoming aware of the scope of the problem; A copy of the press release announcing the recall is attached We will also be running newspaper ads starting tomorTow 7 May dealing

We also put a hold on all of the affected product that was within our control.  Ongoing testing revealed that the presence of the bacteria triggered a chain zeaciion which led to e formation of a byproduct by the name of methyl isothiocyanate (MITC), a toxic substance. MITC can cause Various forms of discamiort, including eye, nose and throat isritation, dizziness, coughing, and wheezing, If inkałed in sufficient quaniities. -  We have no evidence that any of the affected product reached the retail distulbution channel.. However, ił is possible that some of it did, and we cannot ezsily or quidkiy verify that fach, Aocordingly, because we are dealing with a toxic subsiance, we decided out of an abundance of caulłon to ineltute a nationwide. consumer recal|. _ As a result, we are zecalling in the U.8. domestic matket every -  „. padkof cigarettes, both at retail and wholesale, of all of the brands shown. on the z atiachad list. We will also be running newspaper ads starting tomorrow. 5-  8: CE Ę

A detailed proposal is attached, showing estimated cost of $18,000. These respondenta would s be contacted at point-of-purchase and briefly interviewed, The estimated cost of this study ia $18,000, and would take four weeks to complete, with topline two weeks later and final report two weeks after that (eight weeks total, including Store cooperation) .  PGM teacher: Sk ce; M. J, Burno 0363L  OOONEEEOEEEEEEEEEEEEEZEEZZZZZEE aan

The number Of nonparenchymal cells was doubled aftak treatnont with nathapyrilene for two weeks while that of bepa- kocytes zemalned constant. The hexokinase activity was Incroasad fourfold in the nonparenchymal cell fractton while SE was unchanged  ==" in the parenchymal cells, The glucekinasa activity was decreased in the hepatocytes to one third. Hence, thc insteased haxokinase acti- Yzty was due ta a proliferation Of Ronparenchymal cells rather than to a toxic dedifferentiation of hepatocytas. -  "ha antihistaminic drug nethapyrilene was used therapauticaliy until its caresnogenie potency was recognized 2 few years ago. After 1eng-tezn adninistratzon to rats hepatocelluler careznonas develop 11). tlowevex, leng before preneoplastic Foci ocewx, osie alterations . are observed mainly in the periportal zone of the liver acinus (2). These nozphological chonges are acconpanicd by an inversion of the metabolic zonation, whieh is indicated by an increase in haxokinase (ZG 2.7.1.1) in the periportal zona and decrease Of glucokinasa  s (ZE 2.7.1.2) in the perivenous zone of the liver acinue (3). How ever, no conclustve information is available, whether the increase of haxokinase is due to parenchywal (PC) or to nonpatenchymal colls (NBC). Therafore, in the present study, tha hexckinase and tho gluco- , kinase activities were determined in parenchymal and nonparenchynal d ©e118 separatod trem livers of mathapyrilene treated animals, TRe hezokinasa was increased fourfold in tha nonparenchymal cell £ractzon by srhancenent of the nonparenchyal cell number as well as by an Anoxease of the collulsx level of the enzyme. Text ING: CTR PROGRESS REPORT ([or Competing Renewal Application) Grant number 3076 Progress Period from Jul to: Nov_93 Name of Investigator: Robert Rhoads Title 0f Original Grant: Protein Synthesis InitfatIon Factor 4E and Oncogenesis Abstract of the Specific as stated in the original application; Detect, purify and identify the putative elF-4E kinase  Extracts from cells in which phosphorylation of elF-4E can be rapidly induced by an extracellular stimulus will be separated by HPLC and assayed for kinase activity using clF-4E as substrate. Extracts from non-activated cells will serve as controls to rule out constitutive kinase activities B. Establish whether ras is the signal transduction pathway leading to cIF-AE phosphorylation Two systems will be employed: Xenopus oocytes microinjected with activated ras protein and continuous rat embryo fibroblast line transformed with the human baldder carcinoma T24 activaled gene Initially we will measure the rate of elF-4E labcling with the fraction f elF-4E in the phosphorylated state, and the level of elF-4E protein   The more promising system will bc pursued, and strategies will be developed for manipulating the level of cIF-4E and the activity of the ras system t0 determine whether there is - causal linkage. Examine naturally arising human' tumors for perturbations in elF-4E, Samples of human breast; colon and brain tumors will be tested by Westem blotting for elF-4E levels and comparcd with normal tissues  If consistent trends are detected, additional assays will be conducted to correlate elevated elF-4E levels with the presence of known oncogenes: List all publications (author; title and journal) resulting from the current CTR award that contain aprinted acknowledgmento{ CTRsupport For manuscripts, the designation "in press' means YOu have_ preprint: othenwise use "accepted for publication by submitted for publication to_ or "in preparation: Do not list publications that do not acknowledge CTR support: 1. Text ING: C -t SYMPOSIUM On BIOASSAY MODELS AND INHALATION TOXICITY TAMPA AIRPORT RESORT _ TAMPA, FLORIDA OCTOBER 19 -22 1976 Sponsored- by National Cancer Institute National Institutes of Health This symposium was organized serve a5 type o f workshop and discussion on the the area since the first symposium on the subject et"greyeafg It Kas broadened in its cope include investigations in "Iields other than cigarette smoke research Approximately 80 people were expected to attend In fact only 50-6 0 people attended sone for only day The discussion wa s lacking on many papers probably due to the diversity of the participant's interests to the size of the group and to the sontiTobaccagaoee Dr_ Nettesheim_ who was to present paper "Tobacco Bioassay in Rzts became il1 at the last moment and did not attend. His paper was not given . The tone of the meeting was that of genuine scientific interest in the problems of inhalation toxicity testing No anti: smoking zealots were present or at least kept quiet if they were found the meeting very helpful in better understanding the ems involved and in the gress that has been made _ Individual papers are discussed below. Introductory_Paper Gehring, Dow Chemical Company Dr Gehring emphasized the need to assess hazards in real life situations this context nearly al1 ffects are the result o f inhalation exposure  He stated that natural hazards may be greater than man - hazards capability 0f ass= essing such hazards is very limited at this timne For instance, in 1975 there were only 14 laboratories capable of handling only 26 chenicals for inhalation testing- There are few adequately trained personnel in this area Practical tra ining 1n an inhalation laboratory is much more important than formal training- Dr _ Gehring stressed several times that the hazard mus assessed not simply the toxicity This means Chat the number of animals used must be Thorough more important than extensive "hascoghtEGGsgy_ Patho industrial chemicals 12 _ month exposure realistic inhalation conditions hrs/ days/week is usually adequate the case of submarines space ships etc. 24 hour exposure 1 days/week is necessary Probl pro  PettY The made adequa logy day

Text Adam: Śueśtlone Tor DAVID_B. FISHEL from Richard Kluger 1. Though still a relatively young man, you've aeen RJR through a . number of major ups and downs, Generally speaking, what has that been like for you -- and how do you feel, As a native of the comnun- łty -- the corporate and oivie morale has fared? ek ż. The conyentional wisdom regarding RJR's modern leadership runs © something like thist The conpany reached ite apex under the Wnitekor- Darr-Bownan Jr. era when it ASBumed the industry leadership, Then there was a dearth of home-grown talent and the company paid a price for m oertain insularity in Ste structure and porsonnej; suddenly there wasn't enough fresh blood żo provide strong leadership for a . new, and more competitive day, And into this relative vacouum stepped m string of Yankees who had alleged strength in marketing but did not relate Wel]. to the company owlżure and -- more to the point -- were not tobacco men, with zemtinę damage to the company. To what eX- tent, if any, do you find validity to thie sort of analysis? 3. To what extent do you feel the company's early diyersifiontion efforte -- I have in mind especially Sea-Land, Aminoil, and Del Monte -- diverted energy, funds, and qorporate focus from RJR's prime business? 4, In the attention paid to Philip Morris'e asoendancy, most obser- Vers lost sight of the fact that RJRT essentially held lts market share, remained enormously profitable, and continued as a etrong presence in the industry'B struggle against the antismoking movement. Given your specialty, Ao you feel RJRT got something of a dim rap'over the yemrs -- and that Philip Morris, something of a one-brand wonder, got rather more pralse and ink than it merited? 5. I'm struck by what geens to me one of the industry's toughest di- lenmas -- namely, its inabliity, Jareely for fear of inviting liability : suits, to point out to the public that n response to the health issue, almost, every Glgarette manufacturer has over the docados nożably mode ified lts produot line, thereby giving consumers m wide choice in the strength of brands they are free to chooge from among, Instead of denyina thę nędicmi chsrgoe against enoklne, why hasn't the industry ginply said, in effect: Ws don't happen to agree with these arguments, but we recognize they mre out there And we are providing products that will eerve to answer these Goncerns,... 6. My reading of tha clips on the industry's recent history suggeBta that you are emong the most outspoken or defiant oritics of the anti smoking movement. To what extent were you involved with -- or suppor- %ive of -- the 1981 eeries of RUR advertisements in defense of enoking and arguing that the scientific case is far from GloBed? 7. What aspecte of the antismoking movement have caused you and the company the groatest difficulty? By and large, do you feel the presz has given the tobacco industry a fair break in its coverage of the . smoking and health question? B. I% seeme to me that the evidence Bo far produced regarding the mlleged risk to health from passive smoking (BTS) is vastly |ess persuapive than the body of research in connection with direct smoking, and yet it is the ETS iesue that seema to have ignited the antimoking crusade -- A real irony, Why should this be go, and to what extent, : 50771 3505

Donigor, Senior Attorney Natural Resourcań Defenga Council 1991 Intornaticnal Conferenea oh CHG . and Halon Alternatives Hyatt Regency, Baltinore - Decenbar 3, 1991 Ona yaar ago, when I last had the honor of addrossing this conference on CFC and halon alternativós, I offered you ny 1 " gongratulatione for tha progroas that had boan nadó by then. "Today I must oone bafore you with a different nmesaage —- a chaliangó to cut the current phage-out zchedule for all ozone- dopleting chomicale in half or less, Today, the Nayuxal Resource Defence Council, together with Frłendn of the Zarth and the Environmental Defense Fund, ie subujtting a petitioh to the Environmental Protection Agency, sesking emergency action under the Clean Air Act = . 6, to stop production of CFCs by January 1, 1995; o to stop production of halons and Carbon tetrachloride, > dnuediately, .and production of methyl chloroforn and methyl bromide by January 1, 1993; And o to phase out the use of HCFC-22 and other long=lived , HCFCs in newly manufactured products by 2000, with an sepsę and to all production of those chemicals by 2005, aa In the year since we last mat, tha ccientlfic community has H presented us with unspeakakly bad newa. The 199] scientific assessnents conducted under the Montreal Protocol show that the ozone layer is undergoing much more rapid and widespread geterioration than anyone had feared. Ozone depletion ia no longer a polar abstraction. Serious ozone lonses hava been recorded right overhead. Depletion is no longor conflnsd to winter, wheń most people are ińdoóre or covered up. It ie also sceurring in sumner, when peopie Are outeide and hoavily exposed Ło the sun's rays. Text ING: NEWS RELEASE "FLA 1623 MASSACHLSETTS AVE N WASHINGTON D.C. 20036 (2021 328-54(X] ASSOCIATION OF FLIGHT ATTENDAATS IMMEDIATE RELEASE Contact: Jane Goodman or FOR Jil Gallagher, May 18, 1994 202/328-5400 FLIGHT ATTENDANTS TESTIEY ON NEED FOR AIRCRAFT AIR QUALITY IMPROVEMENTS National President Dee Maki and flight attendant representing the WASHINGTON AFA Attendants, AFL-CIO, explain the harmful effects poor cabin air quality Association of Flight attendants and passengers in testimony today before the House Aviation has on both flight Subcommittee of the full Public Works and Transportation Committee: attendants passengers on many flights are not provided adequate amounts of fresh "Flight National President Dee Maki testifies_ "Thus, they may be exposed to unacceptable air;" AFA of bacteria viruses and other potential health risks without the protection of amounts adequate federal regulations: AFA has received many anecdotal complaints from its members about poor cabin air quality and health dificulties; AFA contacted the Federal Aviation Administration immediately when flight attendants began getting ill; however, the FAA which claimed total jurisdiction over crewmember health and safety in 1975 from OSHA, has failed to make any serious airline effort to address occupational safety and health issues outside the area of cash survivability: attendant Deanne Clarke testifies about her personal experiences with poor cabin air Flight including an incident more than year ag0 during which she and her three colleagues experieniced_devere heafideprobleres on 45-minute flight: began to experience dizziness, and hands started to shake Ihad tunnel vision and the skin on my face felt like nausea my had horrible sunburn; even experienced burning tghtness in my chest and my heart wzs palpitating' Clarke explains_ The llight attendants who were eventually taken to 1 hospital, had been exposed to vaporized fuel exhaust which entered the plane during pre- Jight maintenance ~more - and and

Text ING: OBJECTIVE Evaluate the collection efficiency of the Cambridge filter (CF) specified as the smoke collection device by the FTC nicotine method Determine effect; if any, of the ammonia level of the filler or smoke on the amount of nicotine on second collection device used in the evaluation of CF collection efficiency Message Points for this slide: Two purposes for these studies ~The first was an investigation of the nicotine collection efficiency of the FTC method, using a trap after the Cambridge filter to collect any nicotine which was not retained by the CF. 'The second purpose was to compare collection efficiencies for cigarettes 1 with varying filler and mainstream ammonia levels.

Text ING: DRAFT _ NOT FOR RELEASE FOR MMMEDIATE RELEASE Contact:  Scott Williams March [4, 1998 202/739-0225 Steve Duchesne 202/739-0245 TOBACCO INDUSTRY BEGENS ADVERTISING TO BUILD UNDERSTANDING OF COMPREHENSIVE RESOLUTION WASHINGTON,DC. The nation'$ leading cigarette companies today began advertising t0 inform the American people about the details of the comprehensive tobacco agreement negotiated last June between the industry, state attoreys general, private plaintiffs' lawyers and representatives of the public health community. "Despite all the media coverage since last June, the American people don't really the most significant details contained in this historic agreement said Steven C. Parrish; scnior vice president of the Philip Morris Companies: "When they learn the facts, we believe they will increasingly come to the view that the proposed resolution makes sense &nd will also make important immediate contributions to lowering youth smoking while protecting the rights of adults who use tobacco products  The ads, which have bcen timed t0 coincide with an acceleration of Congressional activity about the proposed resolution, will appear in newspapers and on television and radio stations around the country. The print &nd television ads contain nO visual images beyond the of the agreement negotiated last year. "This is & "just the facts' approach because the public needs to know the facts; said Mr. Parish Advertising offers the most effective way of providing the American pcople with the basic clements of the proposed resolution. "The advertising will also help clear up some misconceptions about the resolution, such the false assertion that the proposed resolution provides legal immunity for the companies Individuals can still sue the companics for actual damages and for punitive damages relating to future conduct  We think the public needs to know things like that in order t0 make an informed judgement about the resolution " more - 1 know and . details

Text ING: FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE CONTACT: John Lenzi 15, 1995 212-880-4119 PHILIP MorrIS APPLAUDS RULING ALLOWING CASTANO APPEAL Philip Morris is very pleased by ruling today issued by U.S: District Judge Okla Jones in the Castano class action case in New Orleans   Judge Jones granted motion filed by Philip Morris and the other defendants to allow them to pursue an immediate appeal to the Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals of his decision to certify certain common issues for class handling: Charles Wall, senior vice president and associate general counsel at Philip Morris, applauded the decision, saying it was the common-sense way to manage the litigation. "This case presents many important legal issues that will inevitably be decided by the Fifth Circuit, and makes sense to have these issues decided now, before both sides embark on lengthy and costly proceedings and preparation_ Wall said: Judge Jones also granted the defendants' motion to stay all proceedings in the trial court until the Fifth Circuit has ruled on the issue of class certification: The companies believe that certification was improper in part; because individual issues predominate _ Philip Morris and the other defendants now plan to ask the Fifth Circuit to decertify the Castano class:  May pretrial

Text ING: David I. Greenberg Vice President, Corporate Affairs Strategy & Development Philip Morris Management Corporation American Hospital Association September 12 1999 It's traditional t0 start a speech likc by saying: am delighted to be here with you today: But in order to accomplish one of my main goals in being here naving an open and honest dialogue with you let me offer an alternative: fcrventl hope am delighted to be here with you today: After all; its not often that Philip Morris executive stands before group of hospital CEO's, presidents and administrators_ Im confident it has never happened before "m ess confident it will ever happen again_ My mind searches for the right metaphor: Is this how Custer felt when he surveyed his predicament at the Little Big Horn? Or how surgeon feels when he learns the group observing in the operating theater is not medica students but group of visiting plaintiffs' malpractice lawyers? How bout the lamb who accidentally wandered into the convention of the sweater manufacturers of America? would Iike to come back to these thoughts at the end of our discussion and ask you to help me find the right imagery, Because my goal is to convince you that sometimes things are just not what they appear to be in the modern era of sound bites and lawsuits, appearances and expectations truly can be deceiving: Let me begin with Yogi Berra story. (Tell story:) That is the story of Philip Morris for the last few years: society has been talking to us but we haven't been listening: We have paid huge price for our deafness and our silence More an this theme later: have succeeded even Iittle bit so far; you may be wondering: who is this guy _ he's not exactly what expected_ Im not: And neither is my company: word about both: am 45. have two pre teen age daughters thirteen and ten: So, husband and father are my two most important titles_ am also lawyer; but on the positive side gave up law practice years ago. started my career by spending six years working first for Ralph Nader and as the lead lobbyist and spokesperson for the Consumer Federation of America_ Probably 1 not the classic stepping stone to senior job with tobacco company: But actually, not s0 strange as preparation for job with Philip Morris_ this then

Text Adam: l ! D Industry Statement by Steven C. Parrish Senior Vice President, Corporate Affairs Philip Morris Companies Inc. - January 2, 1996 Today, the major U.S. cigarette companies have filed comprehensive comtmienis with the FDA challenging its attempr to seize regulatory control ver tobacco products. Our comments explain why we object sa strongly to what FDA has done -- and proposes to do. „And we have endeavored to expose te factual errors, flawed reasoning, and misleading allegations that the agency has ser forth in an effoxe to Justify its illegal action. 1 It is clear that we have major objections to what Commissioner Kessler has said and done. But I want ro emphasize with equal weżgkt that liere js one point on which we all agree: Kids should not smoke; nor shouki they have access to tóbaęco products. Much has already been done to accomplish these objectives. For instance, every state now prohibits the sale of tobacco praducis to minors, and the states are stepping up effoms to enforce their laws. But more can bę done; and shouid be done by those with a sincere interest and, unlike FDA, a legirimate role to płay in addressing this issue. Iadividually, and (trough trade associations, members of the tobacco industry, the retail trade, and the law enforcement community are agpresstvely supporting efforts to fight the „problem of youth access to tobacco producis. We have supponed -- and continie to suppołt -- tougher enforvement of state laws, mandatory minimum-age signage in stores, stringent i proof of age requirements, and other rational measures. And we look forward to seeing the results from bipartisan legislation that Congress passed in 1992 to promote stare efforts to curb tobacco sales to minors. That's wltere Congress placed tesponsibility -- not wita FDA, but with the $tates. Since July 1992, 30 states have enacted youth access legislation as a result of Congresv" actions, and FEHS is finally set to issue roles implementing the 1992 law. Text Adam pl: l ! D Industry Statement by Steven C. Parrish Senior Vice President, Corporate Affairs Philip Morris Companies Inc. - January 2, 1996 Today, the major U.S. cigarette companies have filed comprehensive comtmienis with the FDA challenging its attempr to seize regulatory control ver tobacco products. Our comments explain why we object sa strongly to what FDA has done -- and proposes to do. „And we have endeavored to expose te factual errors, flawed reasoning, and misleading allegations that the agency has ser forth in an effoxe to Justify its illegal action. 1 It is clear that we have major objections to what Commissioner Kessler has said and done. But I want ro emphasize with equal wezgkt that liere js one point on which we all agree: Kids should not smoke; nor shouki they have access to tobaeco products. Much has already been done to accomplish these objectives. For instance, every state now prohibits the sale of tobacco praducis to minors, and the states are stepping up effoms to enforce their laws. But more can be done; and shouid be done by those with a sincere interest and, unlike FDA, a legirimate role to play in addressing this issue. Iadividually, and (trough trade associations, members of the tobacco industry, the retail trade, and the law enforcement community are agpresstvely supporting efforts to fight the „problem of youth access to tobacco producis. We have supponed -- and continie to suppolt -- tougher enforvement of state laws, mandatory minimum-age signage in stores, stringent i proof of age requirements, and other rational measures. And we look forward to seeing the results from bipartisan legislation that Congress passed in 1992 to promote stare efforts to curb tobacco sales to minors. That's wltere Congress placed tesponsibility -- not wita FDA, but with the $tates. Since July 1992, 30 states have enacted youth access legislation as a result of Congresv" actions, and FEHS is finally set to issue roles implementing the 1992 law. FDA's rules would mellify dozens of state youth acces laws. Tie rules are an end-run around Congress — and che States. "While the FDA's plan actwally does include youth access restrierions that the industry has PJ previousty supported, such as a minimum sales age and identification requirements, the " Agency proposts far more than prevencing youth access. I seeks to ban practices and rd inipose requirements that will not keep kids from smoking -- but will interfere with the rights — ZR of adujt smokers and the rights of the companies to sell their produes. tw > 2 4

Contrary to speculation in The Wall Street Joumal, Philip Morris U.SA does not use ammonia in the cigarette manufacturing procass to increase the amount of nicotine inhaled by the smoker or to "affect the rate of absorption of nicotine in t0 the bloodstream of the smoker; or to "increase the potency of the nicotine smoker actually inhales_ If, as The Wall Street Journal assers_ Philip Morris U.SA were using ammonia t0 increase nicotine deliveries of lower tar cigarettes one would expect that as tar and nicotine deliveries of Marlboro have failen over the past twenty years; ammonia levels would have increased: But that simply not tne case; over the past 25 years the amount of ammonia has remained nearly constant ' This , of course, is precisely the opposite of what one would expect it,as The Wall Street Joumal arid others have charged, Philip 8 Morris U,S,A_ were using ammonia to enhance nicotine delivery to smckers_ 1 Colby chili Those

Text Adam: FE For Immediate Release Contact: March 24, 1994 Victor Han Philip Morris U.S.A. 202/637-1566 ENILIP MORRIS COMPANIES INC- SUES ABC FOR LIBEL Philip Morris Companies Inc. filed a $10 billion libel lawsuit today against American Broadcasting Companies Inc. for false and defamatory statements made on ABC's "Day One" show and other news prograns. The suit, which also names several ABC employees, was filed in the Virginia State Circuit Court in Richnond, a city where Philip Morris has extensive cigarette=manufacturing operations. The essential allegation made by ABC on those broadcasts was that cigarettes are "artificially spiked" with nicotine during the manufacturing process "in order to keep people smoking." "These allegations are not true and ABC knows they are not. true," said Murray Bring, senior vice president and general counsal of Philip Morris Companies Inc. *There is no corporation in this country more committed to £reedom than is Philip Morris. "As the manufacturer of a controversial product, we well understand the importance of all our freedoms — including a free press that speaks for and to the diversity of this country. uBut we do — we must — draw the line at libel," Bring said. Bring said the facts are clear: nicotine occurs naturally in tobacco leaf and Philip Morris does not in any way, shape or form spike its cigarettes with nicotine during the manufacturing process. vThere is, in fact, a net loss of nicotine during the = cigarette-nanufacturing process. That net loss — for every wm |. Philip Morris brand without exception —— runs 20 percent to 00 25 percent," he said. go i s In fact, the overall nicotine content in cigarettes has co decłined by more than 50 percent over the last 40 years, hd according to Bring. ps

"As the manufacturer of a controversial product, we well understand the importance of all our freedoms — including a free press that speaks for and to the diversity of this country. uBut we do — we must — draw the line at libel," Bring said. Bring said the facts are clear: nicotine occurs naturally in tobacco leaf and Philip Morris does not in any way, shape or form spike its cigarettes with nicotine during the manufacturing process. vThere is, in fact, a net loss of nicotine during the = cigarette-nanufacturing process. That net loss — for every wm |. Philip Morris brand without exception —— runs 20 percent to 00 25 percent," he said. go i s In fact, the overall nicotine content in cigarettes has co declined by more than 50 percent over the last 40 years, hd according to Bring. ps

Text Adam: Contact: Andy Clark or Jim calhoun Edelman Sports 312/280-7678 Xor_Innediate Belenss HARLRORO RACING TEAM PRNSKE RRAVELS 0 AUSTRALIA March 8, 1991, Reading, PA -- For the first tine ever Marlboro Racing Team Penske will set down on Australian soil Saturday March 9 in preparation for the March 17 Gold Coast Indy Car Grand Prix. Although transporting the cars is nothing new to Harlboro Racing Team Penske (chassis” are shipped annually from Penska Cars in Poole, England), the difficulty arises in moving an entire team and limiting the amount of equipment to conply with weight restrictions iuposed by CART. Zach team is allowed one paliet (a portable platform designed for shipping cargo) tor each car being sent and one pallet of equśpnent (up to 5,000 pounds) for each car competing in the race (back-up cars are not allowed a separate pallet of equipnent). According to Team Penske Coordinator Tim Lombardi, "due to weight restrictions we have to limit the amount of equipment we send. This neans that we have to sit back and decide what ia absolutely necessary to send to Australia to be competitive. 8 When we race in North America, we travel by truck and we send as $ mach equipnent as we choose. Now we have to be mich more $ selective." r —nore-

Zach team is allowed one paliet (a portable platform designed for shipping cargo) tor each car being sent and one pallet of equspnent (up to 5,000 pounds) for each car competing in the race (back-up cars are not allowed a separate pallet of equipnent). According to Team Penske Coordinator Tim Lombardi, "due to weight restrictions we have to limit the amount of equipment we send. "Underage Sale Prohibited" Notices Now Being Added to Cigarette Packs RICHMOND. August 8. 1995 Philip Momis U.S.A today announced that production of cigarette packs and cartons of various brands containing the notice "Underage Sale Prohibited has begun at all three of its U.S. manufacturing facilities_ The Company indicated that it would add notices to all ofits cigarette brands for sale in the United States as part ofits Action Against Access initiative [aunched in June The objective of Action Against Access is to make it as difficult as possible for minors t0 obtain or purchase Philip Morris cigarettes. "When Philip Morris U. announced the Action Against Access initiative, said the best way to kids away from cigarettes to keep cigarettes away from kids; said Ellen Merlo, Senior Vice President; orporate Affairs_ ~Our action t0 date has been very specific Merlo stated "First; we immediately discontinued free cigarette sampling and the distribution of cigarettes by mail to consumers Today' announcement that notices appearing on our brands serves a5 further proof of Philip Morris U.S commitment to the goal of a marketplace where minors cannot buy cigarettes The notice reinforces the message at retail that it is against the law to sell cigarettes to minors; Philip Morris manufacturing facilities in Richmond  Virginia; Louisville, Kentucky; and Cabarrus; North Carolina began phasing in packaging with the notice earlier this week As of today, all three locations are producing Marlboro packings representing more than 21 percent of total volume, with the notice. Thc Richmond facility will be producing Marlboro Lights soft and our plants in Louisville and Cabamus will be manufacturing Marlboro Lights box with the notice: Merlo said consumers should begin seeing packs with these notices at retail in six to eight weeks more MARLJORO DCNCON HECGES Mprn VRCINLA SLMMS MALLLHENT LIGHTS taRMYF ALHNE MLAYERS 4akr these kecp Fe 8 pack

Text Adam: a a REACTION MECHANISKS TN THE BURNING CIGARETTE 1.8. OSDENE Resta AND DEJĘLĄGĄENT DEPT nicinóiw, %x, 23261  „INTRODUCTION .  IN ANY DISCUSSION OF CHEMICAL REACTIONS IN THE BURNING CIGARETTE IT IS ESSENTIAL THAT WE FIRST DESCRIBE THE PRESENT STATE OF THE ART REGARDING THE BASIC ENERGY RELATIONSHIPS THAT GOVERN THE BURNING PROCESS, USING TEMPERATURE PROFILES AND MAJOR REACTION ZONES I WILL DEVELOP IN SOME DETAIL A MODEL OF THE BURNING CIGARETTE. THIS WILL SHOW MAJOR SOURCES AND STNKS OF ENERGY WHICH DETERKINE THE GENERATION OF VARIOUS CLASSES OF SMOKE PRODUCTS, 1 WILL DESCRIBE SOME MODERN TECHNIQUES THAT HAVE BEEN USED TO CONFIRM THE LOCATIONS OF THE REACTION ZONES AND TO ELUCIDATE THE REACTION MECHANISMS OCCURRING IN EACH.  IT IS IN OUR OWN LABORATORIES, HERE, AT THE PHILIP MORRIS RESEARCH CENTER THAT MANY OF THE TECHNIQUES USING ISOTOPES, BOTH RADIOACTIVE ONES SUCH AS CARBON-14 AND HEAVY ISOTOPES SUCH AS NITROGEN-15 AND OXYGEN-18, HAVE BEEN PIONEERED. I WILL THERE- FORE DRAW HEAVILY ON THE WORK DONE BY MY COLLEAGUES OYER THE LAST DECADE OR SO. PERHAPS I SHOULD SAY AT THE VERY OUTSET THAT I AM REALLY HERE TO REPRESENT THEM AND TO DESCRIBE THEJR 3. QUTSTANDING CONTRIBUTIONS TO OUR UNDERSTANDING OF THE REACTIONS gi WITHIN THE BURNING CIGARETTE. S'  17 SHOULD BE NOTED THAT SOME 2,000 CHEMICAL COMPONENTS - r HAVE BEEN IDENTIFIED IN CIGARETTE SMOKE AT THE PRESENT TIME i  -. AND PERHAPS TENS OF THOUSANDS ARE AS YET UNDISCOVERED. OBVIOUŚLY,
Text Adam pl: a a REACTION MECHANISKS TN THE BURNING CIGARETTE 1.8. OSDENE Resta AND DEJELAGAENT DEPT nicinoiw, %x, 23261  „INTRODUCTION .  IN ANY DISCUSSION OF CHEMICAL REACTIONS IN THE BURNING CIGARETTE IT IS ESSENTIAL THAT WE FIRST DESCRIBE THE PRESENT STATE OF THE ART REGARDING THE BASIC ENERGY RELATIONSHIPS THAT GOVERN THE BURNING PROCESS, USING TEMPERATURE PROFILES AND MAJOR REACTION ZONES I WILL DEVELOP IN SOME DETAIL A MODEL OF THE BURNING CIGARETTE. THIS WILL SHOW MAJOR SOURCES AND STNKS OF ENERGY WHICH DETERKINE THE GENERATION OF VARIOUS CLASSES OF SMOKE PRODUCTS, 1 WILL DESCRIBE SOME MODERN TECHNIQUES THAT HAVE BEEN USED TO CONFIRM THE LOCATIONS OF THE REACTION ZONES AND TO ELUCIDATE THE REACTION MECHANISMS OCCURRING IN EACH.  IT IS IN OUR OWN LABORATORIES, HERE, AT THE PHILIP MORRIS RESEARCH CENTER THAT MANY OF THE TECHNIQUES USING ISOTOPES, BOTH RADIOACTIVE ONES SUCH AS CARBON-14 AND HEAVY ISOTOPES SUCH AS NITROGEN-15 AND OXYGEN-18, HAVE BEEN PIONEERED. I WILL THERE- FORE DRAW HEAVILY ON THE WORK DONE BY MY COLLEAGUES OYER THE LAST DECADE OR SO. PERHAPS I SHOULD SAY AT THE VERY OUTSET THAT I AM REALLY HERE TO REPRESENT THEM AND TO DESCRIBE THEJR 3. QUTSTANDING CONTRIBUTIONS TO OUR UNDERSTANDING OF THE REACTIONS gi WITHIN THE BURNING CIGARETTE. S'  17 SHOULD BE NOTED THAT SOME 2,000 CHEMICAL COMPONENTS - r HAVE BEEN IDENTIFIED IN CIGARETTE SMOKE AT THE PRESENT TIME i  -. AND PERHAPS TENS OF THOUSANDS ARE AS YET UNDISCOVERED. OBVIOUSLY,

Text Adam: May 30, 1574 To: BIL Marketing Department Personnel This ręquesta your assistance in attaining tighter security of sensitive Company information which you posaess or to which you may have access. Security is a necessary discipline at all times in business operations but im especially critical to the Company at this time due to the vast number and significance of many projects in which we are currently involved-=and especially in view of recent "leaks" of new brand and promotional/ advertising programe under development. Disclosure of such information can be of substantial advantage to our competitors and works to undermine the hard work and dędication which all of us try to bring to our contripution_to. Company growth and profita, Accordingly, effective immediately, we're adopting the following program to assure that information remains confidential to those parties directly involved with any sensitive Company matter: | I. Our Own Attitudes - Any program of this nature requires each of us £o become more concerned about the harm that disclosure of sensitive information can cause. Text Adam pl: May 30, 1574 To: BIL Marketing Department Personnel This requesta your assistance in attaining tighter security of sensitive Company information which you posaess or to which you may have access. Security is a necessary discipline at all times in business operations but im especially critical to the Company at this time due to the vast number and significance of many projects in which we are currently involved-=and especially in view of recent "leaks" of new brand and promotional/ advertising programe under development. Disclosure of such information can be of substantial advantage to our competitors and works to undermine the hard work and dedication which all of us try to bring to our contripution_to. Company growth and profita, Accordingly, effective immediately, we're adopting the following program to assure that information remains confidential to those parties directly involved with any sensitive Company matter: | I. Our Own Attitudes - Any program of this nature requires each of us £o become more concerned about the harm that disclosure of sensitive information can cause. Thus, we must assess the sensitivity of all matters we deal with and  , treat each one according to its degree of confidentiality. II. Need to Knoy - Only those parties needing access to sensitive dnioination in OFdGr to make their contribution to the subject should have access to it. This means: A. No copies are to be made of documents entitied TI) "Confidentia1" (unless the originating party grants permission for such copies) or (2) "Secret" (except by the originator). 3. No casual conversation of the subject with any party not directly involved with the matter, including menbers os your family, - €. No smoking of developmental products except behind closed doors. ni. Text Adam pl: DY — EB . o. A. -A WOJ 7-7. HUD DEC 101086.z- DREFT ———ummnum DRAFT —n——"NAEC DRAFT ————n——— DRAFT ——n=mnm— DRAFT „ From Dr. P.M. Lippiello : - - gubject: Meeting of the Committee bn Nicotine Analogue Research, © R On Wednesday, Novsaber 26, (ho first mzeting of the Committee on „* Nicotine Analogue Research (CUNAR) was held. The purposa of tha . committee, as we understand it, is to organize an ex-house research O» program to investigate known nicotine analogues, or to identify neu ; anes, that have minimal cardiovascular activity. . „ The time frame for organizing this program, by request of executive management, wowid ba first quarter, 1987. The following personnel have _ agresd to serve on the comnittec: Dr. P.M. Lippiello, Dr. Thomas", Parfetti, Dr. JI. Dan deBethizy, Dr. Stephen Sears, Dr. John Robinson, Dr. Michael Dube, Dr. Sam Simmons and Dr. John Reynolds (ex officio). R During the course of the mesting it was decided that the most reasonable approach would ba to organize the program around basic h research efforts, as opposmd te creating a dedicated in vivo / in vitro screening and testing pragram for synthetic analogues. This is becatde . the identification of unequivocal pharmacological and cardiovascular andpoints is limited by the state-of-the-art knowledge of nicotine's affneta in general. The consensus was that the final program should be based on exploring the effects of analogues as part of a more general alfort to further define and understand the effects of nicotina. | Therefore it is desirable to make use of laboratories already funded by RUR that ars in a position to test analogues ta.g. Collins, Deadwyler, Crooks, Vessell, stc.). AL least ons of these laboratories has synthstie Cgpabilities ax umll. It was felt that this approach would facilitata starting the program and minimize the time and expense associated with tha organization of new and independent projects in, additional laboratories. mm u : It waz alzo decided that the program would most easily be structured as two separate, but integrated parts. Une would involve the procurament j and/or synthesis of appropriate analogues; this shouid be supported by a " sound stucture-activity (8AR) research affort. The other would be based i on suitable testing paradigms For the compounds obtainad, relying on the j best pharmacological and cardiovascular endpoints available. The major | - - task of the committee, at present,-is-to identify both the endpoints and | laboratories that suppert research in the appropriate arsas. - Ak present, the committae is gathering information. Dr. Parfatti H will research the identity and availability of existing nicotine : analogues. Dr. deBethizy will identify suitable endpoints te study © z cardiovascular effects. Dra._ Lippiello and Robinson w£ll identify both mw i in vitro and in vive pharmacological endpoints, focusing primarily on © 3 CNG effects. Dra. Dube and Sears will explore the available sx-house * .  expertise in analogue synthesis and evaluation of compounds using computerized SAR technology. Dr. Simmons will zerve as a consultant to the comnittee in support of all of these areas.

Text ING: RIReyokt Tobacco Ccmpany R F.KANE REGION SALES MANAGER 227-A South Street SENT VIA E-MAIL Hopkinton, MA 01748 Pl: 508/435-8613 Fax: 508/435-8591 February 28, 1997 To: All Managers Boston Region Subject: GAP / Ceiling Strategy Revision Dear Managers: Attached is a revision for March (KAMGIAMs received similar letter dated 2/26/97 FSC- 45A). addition to the attached key points are as follows. Doral Defense Discounting Doral at higher rates than normal ceiling strategy rates can only be initiated if GPC is discounted at higher than their normal $.20/82.00 5.30/33.00 rates This is a "Defensive" program and we should not sell higher Doral rates if GPC is not at higher rates; i.e., we can only match GPC "tactic for tactic For payment reporting purposes in situations where the retailer is "kicking in" we should only report our portion of the discount rate not the retailer's_ In stores where rates exceed the printed VPRICoupon $.35/53.50 rates we will have t0 use Monarch VPRs or buydown the appropriate "flighted quantity" to mirror GPC's ratelquantity: NOTE to DMe: If you want the ROU to forward this letter to Sales Reps adlor Retaa with mailing on 3/8/97 _ please contact Bob Snow by 3/4/97_ If Bob does not hear Reps will assume you will be handling via voice maillconference call, etc: from you, we Call if you have any questions. 1 Sincerely, Rich : R F_ Kane RFKInsk Attachment CC: R D_ Snow T,J, Fitzin gun

Text ING: July 19, 1999 follow up to our recent conversations regarding assembling comprehensive team (Retail, Wholesale and Manufacturers) to work on proactive_strategy for Market Product"_ we have scheduled meeting for Friday July 30, 1999 in Winston-Salem, NC. Text ING: May 17,` 1990 MEETING ATTENDEES Subject: Minutes of 605 Blending Meeting meet ing was held on May 16, 1990 to discuss the blending process at 605, specifically the use of remnants_ Those In attendance were: Beeson Culp Curtis Dinkins Hanner Hitchell Listed below are the highl ights of the meet Ing: Hith the implementation in-Tine ammoniation of 6-7 (G-7-AE) , 605-11 wili longer ammoniate G-7_ There is an effort underway in R&d to recommend whole bale blending for blends greater than 30,000 pounds Currently at 605-11 whole bale blending is only used when 47,000 pounds of the KN blend is being made Remnants are being used for C30 ad KN blends daily. Kith the current blending and ammoniation processing rates_ the tobacco is being discharged from the bulkers faster than the bulkers are being filled Mason agreed to contact RBD in order to determine the status of the whole blending recommendation it relates to the C30 and KN blends Danny , along with Bob Dinkins and Steve Armstrong, will tdevelo-Bovosed production schedules for the following cases, assuming that will only ammoniate C30 and KN (i.e., no G-7A): Blend ing Rennants Feed_Rate Case yes 26,000 Ib/hr Case 26,000 Ib/hr Case 3 20,000 Ib/hr luiti #: Curtts 7 CHC:ag:3192g 0 cc: Calleson Teague Ctate
Text Adam: May 17,;'1990 , MEETING ATTENDEES 8 Subject: Minutes of 605 Blendiny Meeting A meettag was held on May 16, 1990 to discuss the blending process at 605, specifically the use of renmants. Those in attendance were: 3. H. Beęson D. 6. Culp c. H. Curtis R. L. Dinkins C. 6. Hanner J. M. Mitcheni Listed below are the highlights of the meeting: + With the implementation of in-1ine anmoniatton of 6-7 (G-7-AE), 605-11 widl no longer anmoniate 6-7. * There is an effort underway in RAD to recommend whole bale biending for blends greater than 30,000 pounds. + Currently at 605-11 whole bale blending is only used when 47,000 pounds of the KW blend is being made. | + Remnants are being used for C30 and KU blends daily. + With the current blending and anmoniation processing rates, the tobacco is being discharged from the bulkers faster than the bulkers are bedng filled, * Hason agreed to contact RAD in order to deternine the status of the whole blending recommendation as it relates to the C30 and KN blends. + Damy, along with Bob Dinkins and Steve Arnstrong, will develop proposed production schedules for the following cases, assuming that 605-11 will only amnoniate C30 and KN (i.8., no 6-7A): Blending Remnants Feed Rate Case 1 yes 26,000 1b/hr * Case 2 no 26,000 1b/hr tase 3 no 20,000 1b/hr tyka lucza ę 5 CZA 8 CHCzag:3192g H <c: D. A. Calleson R. K. Teague
